_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



DOT Foods, Inc., located in Burley, Idaho, provides refrigeration for warehousing and distribution of food and related products and services. DOT Foods, Inc.?s senior management is not only committed to offer superior service, but also maintains a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding communities. DOT Foods, Inc. administers safety and environmental policies at the facility to ensure compliance with OSHA?s Process Safety Management (PSM) and EPA?s Risk Management Program (RMP). These programs include forklift safety, hazard communications, lockout/tagout, employee safety manuals, manufacturers documentation, and the Emergency Response Plan.



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE



DOT Foods, Inc. is located at 1541 W. 27th Street in Burley, Idaho. The system was designed and constructed in accordance with all applicable federal, state, and local regulations.



The system uses 12,870 pounds of ammonia to provide refrigeration for warehousing and distribution of food and related products and services. The vessels and compressors are located in the engine room. The condensers are mounted on the roof and all of the evaporators are located in their respective freezer/cold storage areas.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



The DOT Foods, Inc. ammonia refrigeration system has many safety features. Much of the safety of the system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system.  For example, DOT Foods, Inc. operates in accordance with OSHA?s Process Safety Management regulation.



Other safety features of the ammonia refrigeration system include: ammonia sensors that sound a facility-wide alarm, an emergency shut down button that kills power to engine room equipment, relief valves on all pressure vessels, and continuous ventilation in the engine room to

prevent ammonia explosions.



In addition to the Uniform Mechanical Code, the facility has based its maintenance program on the industry standard: the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) guidelines. In particular, the IIAR Bulletin 110, "Startup, Inspection, and Maintenance of Ammonia Refrigeration Systems? is used at the facility.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



The DOT Foods, Inc. has no accident history to report.

 



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



DOT Foods, Inc. has an emergency response plan in effect at the facility. The Emergency Response Plan (Plan) is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of the PSM document, which is maintained at the facility. This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:



 1.) To save lives.

 2.) To minimize and avoid injuries.

 3.) To protect the environment.

 4.) To minimize property damage.



DOT Foods, Inc. maintains a safety committee whose members are the designated emergency coordinators for the facility. The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures, which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility. This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year. This Plan will be reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM and RMP regulations, as well as to incorporate facility changes due to the renovation of the facility.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



The DOT Foods, Inc. safety committee, in a continual effort to provide a safe work environment for their employees. 



1. Continues to train all employees in Process Safety Management and the facility Safety Plan/Programs.



2. Continues to have employee involvement in Safety Plan Development.



3. Continues employee involvement through safety team participation.



4. Continues internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed
